headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Democrats Take Aim At Vulnerable New York Republicans; Biden Administration Celebrating One Year Of Inflation Reduction Act; Police Raid Kansas Newspaper's Office And Owner's Home. Aired 7:30-8a ET

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: So the crucial fight for control of the House already underway with Democrats zeroing in on districts that were won by Republicans in 2020 despite being Biden districts that he'd carried before. Republicans control the House by just 10 seats and that means Democrats need to flip six in next year's midterm elections to regain control.Our chief congressional correspondent Manu Raju spoke with one of the Republicans from a blue district outside of New York City and the Democrats trying to unseat him. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) REP. MIKE LAWLER (R-NY):  Truly remarkable. MANU RAJU, CNN CHIEF CONGRESSIONAL CORRESPONDENT (voice-over):  It was a stunner last year giving the GOP a razor-thin House majority. Six Republicans winning in the blue New York suburbs. Now, they're the most endangered. So when President Biden recently called vulnerable freshman Mike Lawler --

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: The kind of Republican I was used to dealing with, but he's not one of the MAGA Republicans.RAJU (voice-over):  -- Democrats like Mondaire Jones, seeking to unseat Lawler, were furious. MONDAIRE JONES, (D) NEW YORK CONGRESSIONAL CANDIDATE:  People were horrified when they heard what Joe Biden had to say. RAJU (on camera):  So did Biden get it wrong?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Biden not only got it wrong, but I think it was just factually, like, absurd.RAJU (voice-over):  Lawler is one of 19 Republicans in districts Biden carried in 2020 whose fate will determine the next majority. LAWLER:  I ran to represent this district. RAJU (voice-over):  Lawler says he's appealing to moderates.

utterances.speaker: LAWLER
utterances.sentences: I don't look at it as a vulnerability. I've won twice in 2-1 Democratic districts. And when the president came to Westchester and he said on stage I'm the type of Republican he could work with.RAJU (voice-over):  But Lawler's opponents are seizing on his votes in the conservative-dominated House. Like when the New York freshman voted to rescind a Pentagon policy reimbursing personnel traveling for abortions. LIZ GEREGHTY, (D) NEW YORK CONGRESSIONAL CANDIDATE:  So he's totally fine with women in the military fighting for his freedom, but he won't even protect their rights. RAJU (voice-over):  Lawler defends his vote.

utterances.speaker: LAWLER
utterances.sentences: Using taxpayer funds to pay for travel related to abortion services -- we don't do that.RAJU (voice-over):  Lawler could soon be in another difficult spot if the House tries to begin an impeachment inquiry into Biden.

utterances.speaker: LAWLER
utterances.sentences: I think, for me, with respect to impeachment, we're not there yet.RAJU (voice-over):  Another complication -- the prospect that Donald Trump could be atop the ticket as he faces criminal charges.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Mike Lawler cannot run away from Donald Trump, and this is a district that hates Donald Trump.RAJU (on camera):  Do you think that Trump deserves to be in jail?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: I think Trump deserves to be in prison. But you know what? Let's leave that up to the juries to decide.RAJU (voice-over):  Lawler is critical of Trump's actions after he lost in 2020 --

utterances.speaker: LAWLER
utterances.sentences: I think Donald Trump's conduct post-election was wrong. It was wrong.RAJU (voice-over):  -- but not saying if he'd back Trump as a nominee. RAJU (on camera):  Would you support Trump if he's the nominee?

utterances.speaker: LAWLER
utterances.sentences: Look, at the end of the day, the Republican primary voters are going to choose who the nominee is. I want the party to move in a different direction.RAJU (voice-over):  Though he has his limits.

utterances.speaker: LAWLER
utterances.sentences: If he's convicted, he should not be running for public office, period.RAJU (voice-over):  Lawler says Jones, who used to represent a more liberal New York district, is out of step.

utterances.speaker: LAWLER
utterances.sentences: You're not a pragmatist. You're a political hack.RAJU (voice-over):  But Jones' primary opponent, Liz Gereghty, says this.

utterances.speaker: GEREGHTY
utterances.sentences: He's taking positions that I think are going to cause him problems in a general election.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: I understood those words, which are very, in retrospect, poor choices of words.RAJU (voice-over):  Many voters here are still up for grabs.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Nobody's won my vote yet, you know?RAJU (on camera):  Now, in a sign of just how important a district like this one is for the fight for control of the House, Speaker Kevin McCarthy super PAC released a memo just this week detailing what it is calling the "Blue State Project," saying the House will be won or lost in Democratic strongholds like this one. And McCarthy, himself, plans to travel to New York later this month. Manu Raju, CNN, Piermont, New York. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: PHIL MATTINGLY, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: And joining us now, a Republican strategist, Joe Pinion. And Democratic strategist and former executive director of the New York State Democratic Party, Basil Smikle.I want to get to Manu's beautifully windswept hair --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes, it was.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: -- in a minute.But I want to start, Basil, with your reaction to what President Biden said about a frontline Republican -- potentially, majority-maker -- earlier this year.

utterances.speaker: BASIL SMIKLE, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST, FORMER EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR, NEW YORK STATE DEMOCRATIC PARTY
utterances.sentences: It's vexing.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Yes. SMIKLEBut I would take Mondaire Jones, for example -- a really strong leader. He wound up having to leave that district to go run in another district in the southern part of New York City --

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Through the redistricting --

utterances.speaker: SMIKLE
utterances.sentences: -- through the redistricting --

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: -- that was largely responsible for the --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I think --

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: -- House Republican majority.

utterances.speaker: SMIKLE
utterances.sentences: Correct --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMIKLE
utterances.sentences: -- which is --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMIKLE
utterances.sentences: -- which we actually have to come back to because a judge threw out those lines and we have to redraw them again.So there's a lot of turmoil --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMIKLE
utterances.sentences: -- here, but there is certainly a lot of opportunity for Democrats in 2022.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Joe, you ran for Senate in New York. You know what it's like to run as a Republican in New York.What's interesting to me is those Republicans picked up those seats when the economy was worse. I'm not saying people feel good about the economy now -- they don't -- but inflation was more vexing an issue for Democrats. How about now --

utterances.speaker: JOSEPH PINION III, REPUBLICAN STRATEGIST
utterances.sentences: Well, look, I think there are plenty of issues --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: -- for Republicans? PINIONI think if you look at what President Biden was able to do, he played his trump card -- no pun intended. He emptied the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. He was able to help ease those gas prices down. He was able to lean on the fact that inflation -- they call transitory -- were starting to come down. But I've often said, and we talked about this in the green room, that if you're looking at what we're going to be dealing with moving forward, you're going to have gas prices for heat and energy. Come this winter, they're going to be astronomical without that safety valve to be able to be pulled again. You're going to be dealing with the fact that we are now seeing again people defaulting on their car payments. The fact that the credit card debt now topping a trillion dollars. The fact that the median amount of savings has gone down precipitously and continues to come down, all while baby boomers are retiring to the tune of about 10,000 per day. So those are the type of perfect storm conditions that end up with you staring down the barrel of a 2024 election with the average people saying yes, the macro economy might be doing well, but the micro issues -- the issues that everyday Americans decide their lives on -- those are the ones that are really going to be putting down with pressure on that middle class.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: But isn't it harder -- a little bit harder for Republicans this time around in this state?

utterances.speaker: PINION
utterances.sentences: I don't -- I don't think so. I think, honestly, the real issue is going to be who is going to be at the top of the ticket. What are those issues going to be?I think, again, people can say whatever they want about President Trump. I don't know anyone who is a public figure or private figure who gets indictment four times and is stronger because of it. So that is certainly going to be --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PINION
utterances.sentences: -- a difficult thing for President Trump, a difficult thing for the party, and Democrats have already proven they're going to try to take those indictments and put them around the neck of every single Republican up and down the ballot.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMIKLE
utterances.sentences: To a trial that --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Well, let's --

utterances.speaker: SMIKLE
utterances.sentences: -- he might end up seeing.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Let's listen to how voters in Iowa -- you may have heard the Iowa State Fair is ongoing right now. A lot of politicians are there this weekend. Here's how some Iowa voters feel about those indictments.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: KYUNG LAH, CNN NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Are the indictments changing how you feel?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: No, because I do think a lot of that is for effect.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: A lot of those are trumped up.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I don't believe most of it, you know? They're just out to get him, you know. It might turn around, too. They might -- Biden might be the first one in jail.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: That was our Kyung Lah who talked to a whole lot of reporters over several days in Iowa. So they seem to think nothing to see here.

utterances.speaker: PINION
utterances.sentences: Look, I think if you're talking about the confines of the Republican primary, certainly, this is not really going to affect President Trump.I think if you're talking about the general election, we are really focusing on those anywhere from 14 to 16 percent of people who say they are undecided today, most of whom are registered Independents themselves. And those are the individuals that I think -- the individuals, like Mike Lawler, people like Anthony D'Esposito --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PINION
utterances.sentences: -- here in New York, were able to convince in this '22 cycle that the direction that Joe Biden was taking the country in was not for the best.And I think, again, it is still going to be the economy, stupid. We're still going to be talking about those economic indicators for the forgotten people on Main Street. I think that is going to be the message the Republicans who are successful in 2024 are going to stick to. Those who kind of get lost in these cultural wars. Particularly, these swing districts are going to be able to be the ones that somehow find themselves on the wrong end of the pendulum.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: I think it's a good point because we try and view things through the prism of Trump or Biden. It's a national election. And those voters that Kyung was talking to had tons of great sound. It gives a great window into a Republican primary voter in Iowa, which is a very specific type of Republican primary voter, are not the voters who are going to decide --

utterances.speaker: SMIKLE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: -- in November of 2024.And so, my question is and has long been if you are the Biden campaign, do you want to run against former President Trump right now because he has all this baggage? Because he has all these issues?

utterances.speaker: SMIKLE
utterances.sentences: Well, just -- and I quick thing.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMIKLE
utterances.sentences: There's an Iowa voter, but there's also a New Hampshire voter. You can have --

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Which is a very different voter.

utterances.speaker: SMIKLE
utterances.sentences: Which is a very different voter.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: SMIKLE
utterances.sentences: You can have Independents voting in that primary so it could change the calculus, depending on -- you know, depending on the outcome.Having said that, listen, I do think Trump presents a really important foil for the Democrats for a thousand issues. But I do think that when you consider these issues of democracy -- the reproductive rights, which are still top of mind for so many voters -- particularly, suburban voters, as you talk about.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: And some Republicans.

utterances.speaker: SMIKLE
utterances.sentences: And Republicans. So if you -- if you cobble together Democrats who are firmly behindJoe Biden in ways that Barack Obama wasn't at this time in his presidency, if you add those Independent voters that you're talking about, and you add disaffected Republicans -- those that were so helpful to Democrats in 2022 -- if we can still keep that coalition it bears well for anybody that Joe Biden has to go up against in 2024.

utterances.speaker: PINION
utterances.sentences: Look, I've long said you cannot rebuild the Obama coalition without an Obama on the ballot. And the only way that it actually came back together was a once-in-a-generational pandemic. It effectively changed the entire landscape of the 2020 race.So I think --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: PINION
utterances.sentences: -- what people aren't talking about -- Joe Biden in 2024, a much different man from Joe Biden in 2019-2020. I think the personal issues and the political baggage will lead to this being a more interesting race than some people are giving it credit.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Joe, thank you.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Right, and particularly, given the scale in terms of the time horizon for all of these things to take effect and to really be felt. And I should note it's not just Julia's opinion. The president --

utterances.speaker: CHATTERLEY
utterances.sentences: He said it last week.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: -- he said it at a fundraiser.

utterances.speaker: CHATTERLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, he did.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: So at fundraisers, President Biden is the best as a reporter because he's far more candid even though he's not on camera. And he said, quote --

utterances.speaker: CHATTERLEY
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE)

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: -- "I wish I hadn't called it that because it has less to do with reducing inflation than it has to do with providing alternatives that generate economic growth."

utterances.speaker: CHATTERLEY
utterances.sentences: Yes --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Julia --

utterances.speaker: CHATTERLEY
utterances.sentences: -- but you did it for a reason.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CHATTERLEY
utterances.sentences: It was the wrong name --

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Well --

utterances.speaker: CHATTERLEY
utterances.sentences: -- and now you've got to change the name.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: But they got the policy in.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So, politically --

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Maybe that's what matters and it's going to (INAUDIBLE) over time.

utterances.speaker: CHATTERLEY
utterances.sentences: But they're not getting credit for it.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CHATTERLEY
utterances.sentences: And in Republican --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CHATTERLEY
utterances.sentences: -- states this is going to matter more and more because they're going to get credit for the investment and, hopefully, the jobs that come from it.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CHATTERLEY
utterances.sentences: So --

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: It's fascinating, Julia. A lot more to come.

utterances.speaker: CHATTERLEY
utterances.sentences: -- it's all the message better.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Julia Chatterley, thank you.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Well, the raid of a newspaper headquarters in Kansas is raising serious concerns over First Amendment rights. Police seizing everything from computers to servers, to cell phones of reporters and editors. How the paper is responding. That's next.(COMMERCIAL)

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So the owner said that the searches appear to be connected to an investigation by the newspaper into how that newspaper obtained information related to a local restaurant owner. The restaurant owner accuses the paper of illegally obtaining and sharing documentation on a DUI citation she received about 15 years ago. The newspaper reports it was a source that shared the information with a reporter and they confirmed it through publicly available records. They also decided not to publish the information until after the restaurant owner started publicly accusing them of wrongdoing.Our senior media reporter and analyst Sara Fischer joins us now. This is really much bigger than this paper, right? It matters what's happening here because it matters. It's a First Amendment question. You rarely see a raid like this happen. How did this happen and was it legal? SARA FISCHER, CNN SENIOR MEDIA ANALYST, SENIOR MEDIA REPORTER, AXIOS (via Webex by Cisco):  It's a great question, Poppy. And just to hit at your first point there, this is part of a broader trend within the United States of law enforcement and journalism companies going head- to-head. We've seen the U.S. Press Freedom Tracker has tracked that this has been increasing since the George Floyd protests in 2020. We saw hundreds of journalists get arrested. There were warrants issued for them to give over their footage. And so, when we hear about something happening like this at a local paper it's a reminder that this is part of the bigger problem in the U.S. I cover a lot of press freedom rights around the globe in autocratic countries. You rarely see things like this -- a raid like this at a local paper here in the U.S. Right now, it seems that there is a discrepancy between whether or not the paper was supposed to be raided -- whether there was legal grounds to do it. You mentioned at the top there's 34 news organizations joining the press freedom groups, arguing that this is against federal privacy law. That this is against federal law to do it. Of course, the local law enforcement is pointing at different situations, saying that they had grounds to invade the home of this newspaper executive. Time will tell once we get a better sense of what's going on with the story. But for now, you have a lot of journalists very worked up over this situation.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, look, Sara -- and you cover this stuff every single day -- it's, on its face, completely ridiculous. And I think it was stunning and got more stunning every single paragraph I would read about this story over the course of the last several days.What is your sense in terms of whether or not the rationale and justification from law enforcement holds up?

utterances.speaker: FISCHER
utterances.sentences: My sense is that it doesn't. I mean, like I said, it's very rare for law enforcement to raid a home like this, in part because we have such strong protections for the press and for the First Amendment that it's typically very hard for them to do something like this.But again, if they're trying to say that the reason they did it is because someone from the newspaper is involved in what they're trying to investigate, if that turns out to be the case I might feel a little bit differently. But we just don't have enough details right now, Phil, to be able to understand their rationale, which is why I think that this type of situation --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FISCHER
utterances.sentences: -- is unprecedented and totally uncalled for.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: One of the -- the owner of the paper also tried to get from the judge the probable cause affidavit that would have led to the search warrant and was not able to obtain it because the judge told them that didn't exist.And what I think is really notable here -- they're still trying to get their weekly edition published, Sara. They're working on guests -- people -- friends, acquaintances, laptops, et cetera to get it out on Wednesday morning. And it just speaks to the dedication to journalism -- to the profession.

utterances.speaker: FISCHER
utterances.sentences: Yes, you've seen this time and time again throughout the year. Remember that Las Vegas --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FISCHER
utterances.sentences: -- Nevada journalism reporter who was killed. They still had to get a paper out the next day.I think about a lot of our colleagues in Hawaii right now that are dealing with print newspapers amid big wildfires. This is part of the toughness of journalism. But I hope it works out (audio gap) in Kansas.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: All right. Sara Fischer, we're going to keep our eye on this story for sure going forward. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: FISCHER
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: And coming up, the move from Fulton County district attorney Fani Willis that could signal yet another indictment for former President Trump.
